did.unittitle: Abbey of Gethsemani and Merton Literature

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Abbey of Gethsemani and Merton series includes materials about projects at the monastery and of Thomas Merton. The Abbey of Gethsemani has more than 2,000 acres of farmland, and considered to be the mother house of all Trappist and Trappistine monasteries in the United States of America. From 1948 until his death in 1968 the Abbey of Our Lady of Gethsemani was the home of Thomas Merton. The monks bring money to the abbey by producing cheese, fruit cake and wine. The calendars and pamphlets exhibit pictures and description of the works on the abbey's farm. Also included in the series are book sleeves and anti nuclear proliferation pamphlets created by Thomas Merton while living at the Abbey.
